prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H2O(3_21-3_12), H2O(2_20-2_11), H2O(3_12-2_21), CO(10-9) and HF(1-0)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This setup is aiming at mapping the key high-lying H2O line 6, low excitation H2O line 4 and high-J CO(10-9) lines at a resolution ~0.23" in G09.97, and also we may detect the line line 6 and HF(1-0) in the band when integrate the flux over the whole source.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This setup in band 6 is aiming to cover H2O line 4, 5', 6, CO(10-9) and HF(1-0) lines, and also to ensure that we have enough coverage for measuring the continuum. The 31.250 MHz spectral resolution ensures that we are not having high data rate. And also we will have enough channel element within the line width for scientific analysis.

The largest angular scale for the source is about 2.5" as shown in the Fig 3. of the Science Case. And we are going to choose a ~0.23" resolution in this setup. With this resolution, we will be able to resolve some structures (e.g., velocity gradient) of the H2O, CO and continuum emissions as illustrated in Fig. 3, under the help of gravitational lensing. And according to the ALMA simulation for the continuum and H2O line shown as background image and color contours in Fig. 3, we will not loose the flux at the largest scale.

As listed in Table 1, the peak flux of the main H2O line 6 and 4 are 17.7 and 10.4 mJy, respectively. And for the weakest H2O line 5', the flux is 3.2 mJy. With the requested time in this setup, we will get S/N ratios at 50 km/s bandwidth under summer condition for line 6, 4 and 5' at around 96, 56 and 17 if integrating the flux over the entire source. For the mapping purpose, the source will likely to be resolved into ~9 beams (Fig. 3), thus we will detect H2O line 6 and 4 at >~6 sigma within each beam. CO(10-9) would like to be a bit strong as H2O line 6, thus it also can be resolved with good S/N. According to the local ULIRGs, the strength of HF(1-0) would be 0.2 of the line 6, thus we will be able to detect it at S/N~10 when integrated over the whole source.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H2O(4_22-4_13), H2O+(1_11-0_00) and H218O(3_21-3_12)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This observes the important high excitaiton H2O line 7 in a resolution ~0.23", mapping the spatial structure of the high excitaiton H2O emission. And also we will get line H2O+(1_11-0_00) and H218O(3_21-3_12) observed in the other side band, tracing H2O related chemistry.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This setup in band 6 is to cover H2O line 7, H2O+(1_11-0_00) and H2^{18}O(3_21-3_12) lines, and also to ensure that we have engouh band coverage for the continuum. The 31.250 MHz spectral resolution ensures that we are not having high data rate. And also we will have enough channel element within the line width for scientific analysis.

The largest angular scale for the source is about 2.5" as shown in the Fig 3. of the Science Case. And we are going to choose a ~0.23" resolution in band 6. With this resolution, we will be able to resolve some structures (e.g., velocity gradient) of the high excitation H2O and continuum emissions as illustrated in Fig. 3. And according to the ALMA simulation for the continuum and H2O line shown as background image and color contours in Fig. 3, we will not loose the flux at largest scale.

As listed in Table 1, the peak flux of the main high excitation H2O line 7 is 9.6 mJy. And with the requested time in this setup, we will get S/N ratios at 50 km/s bandwidth under summer condition as 53 for the integrated flux over the entire source. For the mapping purpose, the source will likely to be resolved into ~9 beams (Fig. 3), thus we will detect H2O line 7 at >6 sigma in each beam. according to the ratios given by Yang et al. 2013, H2O+(1_11-0_00) are likely to be 0.3 of H2O line 7. Thus we will also be able to detect this line at >10 S/N level by given assumption. And we will also have change to detect H2^{18}O(3_21-3_12) which is less stronger than H2O+(1_11-0_00).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H2O(2_11-2_02), CO(6-5) and H2O+(202-111)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This observes the key low excitaiton H2O line 3 in a resolution ~0.3", mapping the spatial structure of the low excitaiton H2O emission in the strongly lensed source. Also, we will observe strong CO(6-5) line in the other side band, tracing ordinary molecular gas. Within this setup, we will also have the H2O+(202-111) doublet lines covered.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This setup in band 4 is to cover H2O line 3, CO(6-5) and H2O+(202-111) lines, and also to ensure that we have engouh coverage for the continuum. The 31.250 MHz spectral resolution ensures that we are not having high data rate. And also we will have enough channel element within the line width for scientific analysis.

The largest angular scale for the source is about 2.5" as shown in the Fig 3. of the Science Case. And we are going to choose a 0.3" resolution in this setup. With this resolution, we will be able to resolve some structures (e.g., velocity gradient) of the H2O, CO and continuum emissions as demonstrated in Fig. 3. And according to the ALMA simulation for the continuum and H2O line shown as background image and color contours in Fig. 3, we will not loose the flux at largest scale.

As listed in Table 1, the peak flux of the main H2O line 3 is 16.5 mJy. Thus, with the requested time in this setup, we will get S/N ratios with 50 km/s bandwidth under summer condition at 79. For the mapping purpose, the source will likely to be resolved into ~7 beams (Fig. 3), thus we will detect H2O line 3 line at ~9 sigma in each beam. CO(6-5) would like to be three times stronger than the H2O line, thus offering a much better S/N for the mapping. According to the local ULIRGs (Yang et al. 2013), H2O+(202-111) doublet lines are likely 0.2 times of H2O line 3, thus we will detect this line at S/N ~8 when integrated over the entire source.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Submm multi-line H2O studies provide a unique probe of the densest starburst regions of ULIRGs where they measure the local IR radiation field. Strong gravitational lensing boosts ALMA sensitivity and angular resolution, enabling comprehensive studies of these sources with H2O lines at z~4. The impact of such multi-line H2O observations much benefits from combination with simultaneous high-resolution imaging of the far-IR dust emission and CO lines, as shown in the SV observation of the prototypal source SDP81. Our IRAM/PdBI detection of H2O in 16 high-z lensed galaxies has shown that strong H2O emission is ubiquitous in high-z ULIRGs. As in local ones, our modeling shows that it originates from highly obscured IR-luminous regions. We have selected the best source with high-excitation H2O emission at z=3.63 for a new step of our ALMA high-z H2O project. We will observe 5 H2O lines providing the full diagnostic power of H2O, in 3 tunings in standard ALMA modes. Mapping the FIR continuum and CO(6-5) at 0.25" will provide details of the source structure at 500pc resolution in the source plane, relating H2O emission and excitation to the overall structure and dynamics of the gas disk.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
